author: By Amy Qin
title: The Lesser-Known Side of Harris’s Identity: Asian American
description: Some Asian American leaders are rooting for Kamala Harris to become the first Asian American president. But she is not widely known as Asian American, reflecting the complexity of the identity.
content: Daniel Chiang can remember one Asian American who ran for president in 2020: Andrew Yang, a Taiwanese American entrepreneur. But he was surprised to learn last week that there was another person running for president then, and in 2024, who counted herself an Asian American: Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor, Chang W. Lee and Gabriela Bhaskar
title: Here’s how Simone Biles and her American teammates stormed into the finals.
description: Biles needed tape on her lower leg after an awkward landing, but went on to a solid qualifying performance.
content: The U.S. women’s gymnastics team qualified for Tuesday’s team final with a solid performance on Sunday, led by Simone Biles — competing on a taped leg — and Sunisa Lee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Grilled Chicken With Corn and Lime-Basil Butter, a Fantastic Taste of Summer
description: With blueberry spoon cake for dessert, naturally.
content: Good morning. One of the great American crossroads is the intersection of Route 82 and Church Street in Pine Plains, N.Y., where Clare de Boer has a restaurant, Stissing House. There’s a flatness there, a feeling of being at the center of a valley, as if you’re in a stream bed, the restaurant beside it, warm and old and clean. You’d like to ride a horse there and take a room upstairs to sleep after dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Adam Rasgon
title: Negotiators Meet to Revive Push for Hostage Release and Cease-Fire in Gaza
description: The talks in Rome remain stuck over several key issues, including the extent to which Israeli troops should withdraw from Gaza, where tens of thousands were forced under Israeli orders to evacuate Sunday.
content: Senior officials from Israel, Egypt, Qatar and the United States met in Rome on Sunday to continue negotiations over a cease-fire in Gaza, according to three officials involved in or briefed on the talks and a statement from the Israeli government. The talks came as tensions mounted in the region amid growing violence along the border between Israel and Lebanon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Gammon
title: How Our Bodies Can Adapt to Heat
description: It’s possible to train your body to better handle high temperatures in just a few weeks.
content: Inside a small, sealed room, Olivia Leach swallowed a pill that would soon monitor her internal temperature. She then hopped on a stationary bike and prepared to sweat. Slowly, as she began to pedal, the room started to heat up at a rate of one degree every five minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Berzon and Mike McIntire
title: A Pedigreed Rail Magnate Is Pouring Millions Into Electing Donald Trump
description: Timothy Mellon, a reclusive heir to a storied fortune, is spending tens of millions to elect Donald J. Trump. Precisely what he wants in return is one of many curiosities surrounding him.
content: Timothy Mellon, a wealthy banking heir and railroad magnate, has reached the stratosphere of American political influence as the top supporter of Donald J. Trump, doling out millions to try to elect the former president and his allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel, Daniel Berehulak and James Hill
title: By the smallest of margins, Torri Huske beat her U.S. teammate and managed to heal an old heartbreak at the same time.
description: In third place at the turn, Huske powered to gold, edging her teammate — and world-record holder — Gretchen Walsh at the end by touching just ahead of her.
content: The gold medal that Torri Huske of the United States won on Sunday in the 100-meter butterfly barely eluded her three years ago at the Tokyo Olympics, a letdown that might not have annoyed her so much had she won silver then, or even bronze.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Israeli Evacuation Order Displaces Gazans Again
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 28, 2024.
content: “People aren’t being regarded as people. They’re being treated as pinballs and chess pieces.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Thielking
title: Adapting to the Heat
description: How to help your body adjust to higher temperatures.
content: It has been hot outside. Very, very hot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eli Saslow
title: Racked by Pain and Enraptured by a Right-Wing Miracle Cure
description: With Patriot Party News, Michael Chesebro found a sense of community, and a place where conspiracy theories could become real in the form of the “medbed.”
content: Michael Chesebro awoke to the same reality as he did each morning, with pain radiating up his spine and into his shoulders before he opened his eyes. He remained still for a moment, summoning the courage to reach from his bed to his night stand. He rolled onto his back, which was fused together with metal after almost 20 years as a paratrooper in the military. He extended his arm, which he had broken several times while wrangling bulls and horses on his ranch outside Cheyenne, Wyo. Finally, his hand found his cellphone, and he logged on to the online universe where he spent most of his days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Kamala Harris’s Laugh Is a Campaign Issue. Our Comedy Critic Weighs in.
description: The Trump campaign sees Harris’s laugh as a vulnerability to exploit. But far from a liability, it is one of her most effective weapons.
content: Kamala Harris has an easy laugh. To the campaign running against her, this appears to be a vulnerability to exploit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘Deadpool & Wolverine’ Reverses Marvel’s Box Office Slump
description: The superhero sequel was on pace to collect about $200 million at North American theaters over the weekend, a record opening for an R-rated movie.
content: Marvel Studios, trying to move past a pair of box office humiliations, deployed two of its most popular characters over the weekend and hit a mother lode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Harris Campaign Says It Raised $200 Million Since Biden Dropped Out
description: The one-week total is more than President Biden’s haul in the first quarter of the year. About two-thirds came from first-time donors, according to the vice president’s campaign.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign said on Sunday that it had raised $200 million in the week since President Biden withdrew from the race — more than Mr. Biden’s haul in the first three months of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: 12 Officials Sentenced for Roles in Devastating Libya Flood
description: The officials were punished nearly a year after two dams above the seaside city of Derna failed in a storm, killing thousands and destroying much of the area.
content: Twelve Libyan officials were convicted and sentenced on Sunday for their roles in a disaster that killed thousands of people and wrecked a huge swath of eastern Libya, the country’s top prosecutor said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel, Daniel Berehulak and James Hill
title: Behind a French roar, Léon Marchand leaves the world’s best swimmers in his wake.
description: Marchand, who has been dubbed the “French Michael Phelps,” set the Olympic record in the men’s 400-meter individual medley final.
content: The cheers for Leon Marchand thundered inside La Defense Arena on Sunday as he sat in the call room before the 400-meter individual medley, and then as he appeared in the pool area, as he was introduced in Lane 4, and then as he ascended the starting block, and, then, as he rocketed past seven other swimmers in the water with a ruthless, envious elegance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Hollywood’s Message to Red States: Our Movies Are for You
description: After a period of openly using movies to display progressive values, studios seem to be heeding a message from many ticket buyers: Just entertain us.
content: For nearly two decades, Hollywood has seemingly missed no opportunity to sound the alarm about climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Bensinger
title: Elon Musk Shares Manipulated Harris Video, in Seeming Violation of X’s Policies
description: The billionaire owner of the social media platform X reposted a video that mimics Vice President Kamala Harris’s voice, without disclosing that it had been altered.
content: Elon Musk, the world’s richest man, has waded into one of the thorniest issues facing U.S. politics: deepfake videos.
source.name: The New York Times

title: It’s really a matter of math …
description: There are 10,000 athletes at the Paris Games, spread across 32 sports. In the space of 19 days, that field has to be whittled down to just 329 gold medals. So, ultimately, someone has to go out first.
content: There are 10,000 athletes at the Paris Games, spread across 32 sports. In the space of 19 days, that field has to be whittled down to just 329 gold medals. So, ultimately, someone has to go out first. Here’s what it’s like to go first.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft and Kate Selig
title: Park Fire in Northern California Spreads to 360,000 Acres
description: The fire, the largest active blaze in the United States, was 12 percent contained on Sunday afternoon. Fire activity was on the rise, according to officials.
content: The Park fire in Northern California has grown to more than 360,000 acres under less favorable weather conditions on Sunday, with fire activity picking up again, according to officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,136, Monday, July 29, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: Decoding JD Vance’s Brand of Nationalism
description: What do conservatives mean when they say that America is not “an idea”? The answer is key to understanding the 2024 election.
content: Is America an idea or a homeland? That question lies at the heart of this roller coaster of a presidential race. It’s about whether we Americans should continue to set our sights on global leadership and enforcing universal principles or instead hunker down and take care of our own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell
title: How the Shock of Catastrophic Floods Is Changing Farming in Vermont
description: A growing cohort of young farmers is experimenting with ways to mitigate the impact of flooding and other extreme weather.
content: When they bought their organic vegetable farm in South Royalton, Vt., slung along the fertile floodplain of the White River, Ashley Loehr and Antoine Guerlain took comfort in the dense buffer of shrubs and trees that lay between their fields and the gently swirling water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: ‘Maybe I’ve Gotten Worse’: Trump Makes Clear That Unity Is Over
description: At a rally in Minnesota on Saturday, former President Donald J. Trump once more escalated his attacks against Vice President Kamala Harris, painting her as extreme and mocking her demeanor.
content: Early in his speech in Minnesota on Saturday night, former President Donald J. Trump made clear just how quickly he has jettisoned the appeal for national unity that he made after he survived an assassination attempt in Pennsylvania two weeks ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: A Blood Test Accurately Diagnosed Alzheimer’s 90% of the Time, Study Finds
description: It was much more accurate than primary care doctors using cognitive tests and CT scans. The findings could speed the quest for an affordable and accessible way to diagnose patients with memory problems.
content: Scientists have made another major stride toward the long-sought goal of diagnosing Alzheimer’s disease with a simple blood test. On Sunday, a team of researchers reported that a blood test was significantly more accurate than doctors’ interpretation of cognitive tests and CT scans in signaling the condition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Food as You Know It Is About to Change
description: Our food supply is more fragile than you think.
content: This essay is part of What to Eat on a Burning Planet, a series exploring bold ideas to secure our food supply. Read more about this project in a note from Eliza Barclay, Opinion’s climate editor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: From Believers to Bitcoin: 24 Hours in Trump’s Code-Switching Campaign
description: When Donald J. Trump tries to win over a crowd that is not inherently his own, the results can be awkward.
content: In a matter of just 24 hours this weekend, Donald J. Trump traversed two very different worlds, neither one of them his own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Robert Downey Jr. Set to Return to Marvel as Dr. Doom
description: The actor announced his return to Marvel’s superhero movie franchise five years after ending his long run as Iron Man.
content: Robert Downey Jr. is going from superhero to supervillain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith and James Wagner
title: The Olympics Has a Bad Guy: Anyone in an Argentina Jersey
description: Grudges from the World Cup and rugby union have spilled over to the Games. But is this new sports feud even real?
content: The Olympic Games have long been governed by a tacit code: If fans can’t say anything nice, they shouldn’t say anything at all. Jeering, whistling and catcalling at athletes who have spent years to make it to the pinnacle of their sports is “unacceptable,” as Thomas Bach, the president of the International Olympic Committee, once put it. To boo is, well, taboo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Wray
title: Romeo and Juliet, Plus Guns, Cults and Waco, Texas
description: An infamous 1993 siege provides the backdrop for Bret Anthony Johnston’s novel about star-crossed lovers.
content: What is it about cults? We can’t seem to get enough of them, in whatever format — documentary, feature, series, news, memoir, fiction. We love these stories, I’d argue, for the same reasons people are drawn to cults themselves: the promise of a radical alternative, of emancipation from ourselves, of ideological cover for bad behavior, of simple (if theologically arcane) answers to life’s complex, intractable problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Scholes
title: Remembering the Firebrand Irish Novelist Edna O’Brien
description: Her fiction delivered searing, candid portraits of Irish society through the prism of female friendship.
content: Decades before Elena Ferrante’s Neapolitan novels, the Irish writer Edna O’Brien — who died at 93 on July 27 — provided her own searing portraits of an oppressive, violent society seen through the prism of female friendship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Adams Blocks Law That Bans Solitary Confinement in New York Jails
description: Mayor Eric Adams declared a state of emergency in New York City jails and suspended parts of a law banning solitary confinement, a day before it was to take effect.
content: Mayor Eric Adams declared a state of emergency in New York City jails on Saturday and issued an executive order that blocked key parts of a local law that would have banned solitary confinement in the jails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Jill Biden, Jessica Chastain and Nick Jonas Toast Team U.S.A. in Paris
description: Athletes, actors, and journalists drank champagne and sampled from a raw bar at a party thrown by Ralph Lauren during the first weekend of the Paris Olympics.
content: Just after 10 p.m. on Saturday night, on the first weekend of the Paris Olympics, Jill Biden walked through the wood doors of Ralph’s Restaurant Paris, past a towering display of red, white and blue flowers, and picked up two glasses of champagne from a silver tray.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Monday Briefing: A Deadly Strike on the Israel-Lebanon Border
description: Plus, Venezuela’s election and the Olympics’ first weekend
content: Western diplomats were scrambling to prevent a surge of fighting along the Israel-Lebanon border after a rocket from Lebanon killed at least 12 children and teenagers at a soccer field in an Israeli-controlled town on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev, Frances Robles and Julie Turkewitz
title: Hourslong Lines as Voters Surge to Polls in Venezuela’s Pivotal Election
description: Sunday’s vote could end a generation of control by Venezuela’s socialist party. It could also usher in a period of profound uncertainty.
content: They arrived at polling stations long before dawn, slept in the streets so they could be the first in line, and then cried as they cast their votes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Trump, Appealing to Bitcoin Fans, Vows U.S. Will Be ‘Crypto Capital of the Planet’
description: Donald Trump, speaking at a Bitcoin conference, told cryptocurrency holders that he would end the “persecution” of their industry.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump vowed on Saturday that he would turn the United States into a “Bitcoin superpower" if returned to the White House, wielding much of the same rhetoric of persecution that he has applied to himself and his supporters to appeal to cryptocurrency enthusiasts who want to see less regulation.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Walked Right Into a Tree Branch, an Arm Extended Over the Sidewalk’
description: A block comes to life on a summer day, a Staten Island bird feeder and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: California Highway Reopens After Lithium Battery Fire Trapped Drivers
description: A portion of I-15 near Baker, Calif., fully reopened early on Sunday after a truck carrying lithium batteries caught fire, stopping traffic for hours in sweltering heat.
content: A California highway reopened early Sunday after a fire involving an overturned truck carrying lithium-ion batteries trapped drivers in 109-degree heat for hours on Friday and Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Know What’s Funny About Getting Old? These Movies Do.
description: Star-studded with leading ladies, who are all a bit older, recent comedies like “The Fabulous Four” and “80 for Brady” are establishing a popular new genre.
content: There are two new films this year in which Academy Award-nominated actresses in their 70s whip out tiny sex toys. In “Summer Camp,” Kathy Bates offers up wee vibrators to Alfre Woodard and Diane Keaton. In “The Fabulous Four,” it’s Bette Midler giving Susan Sarandon a kegel ball that she later flings at a bike thief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro
title: Melinda French Gates Is Ready to Take Sides
description: The billionaire philanthropist is turning 60, striking out on her own and getting political.
content: In May, Melinda French Gates said that she was leaving the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, which she helped found in 2000. Despite her divorce from Bill Gates a few years ago, the couple continued working together, and it was understood that Melinda was a crucial part of what made the foundation so effective. It’s hard to overstate what an earthquake her departure was in the world of big-donor charitable giving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: James C. Scott, Iconoclastic Social Scientist, Dies at 87
description: In influential books, he questioned top-down government programs and extolled the power of the powerless, embracing a form of anarchism.
content: James C. Scott, one of the world’s most widely read social scientists, whose studies on why top-down government schemes of betterment often fail and how marginalized groups subtly undermine authority led to his embrace of anarchism as a political philosophy, died on July 19 at his home in Durham, Conn. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: U.S. and Japan Announce Steps to Strengthen Their Military Ties
description: The two governments said the moves were a response to growing aggression by China, whose rapid military buildup has many leaders worried.
content: The top diplomatic and defense officials from the United States and Japan announced on Sunday that their nations would take concrete steps to bolster their military alliance because of the growing threat from China in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Simone Biles Is Done Being Judged
description: Three years after she dropped out of the Tokyo Games with a mental block, she is back at the Olympics with a defiant attitude — and a sense of where she is in the air.
content: Follow live updates of the women’s gymnastics qualifying at the 2024 Paris Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Hinga Klein and Jonathan Weisman
title: Beshear, a Potential Harris V.P. Pick, Rallies Democrats in Deep-Red Iowa
description: Gov. Andy Beshear of Kentucky has shown off his attack dog chops in recent days, offering a message of unity in a state dominated by Republicans — but where Democrats say they’ve seen fresh energy.
content: Gov. Andy Beshear of Kentucky, in contention to be Vice President Kamala Harris’s running mate on the Democratic ticket, tried out for the post in Iowa on Saturday by going after the man he would face on the Republican ticket, telling Iowa Democrats that Senator JD Vance of Ohio has “contrived” his claims to be from Appalachia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Echoes of the Fort McMurray Disaster as Fire Sweeps Into Jasper, Alberta
description: About a third of the buildings in the mountain resort town have burned, raising questions about preparedness and the role of climate change.
content: While I had covered many wildfires by 2016, I didn’t realize the full extent of their destructive energy until I stepped off a bus carrying journalists on the first official tour of Fort McMurray, during the tail end of a fire that had forced the panicked evacuation of the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: A Village’s Anguish Over 12 Children Lost to a Rocket Strike
description: A stunned hush of collective mourning fell over Majdal Shams, in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights, after the attack from Lebanon.
content: The rocket struck on the sideline of the pint-size soccer field, just inside a chain-link fence, where the children of Majdal Shams, a picturesque Druse Arab village in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights, wait their turn to play, or just sit and watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Shane Goldmacher
title: JD Vance Stumbles in His Debut, as Democrats Go on Offense
description: In the 12 days since Ohio’s junior senator was tapped as the future of Donald J. Trump’s movement, old comments and a chorus of derision have blunted any sense of invulnerability.
content: The choice of Senator JD Vance as former President Donald J. Trump’s running mate reflected the confidence of a campaign so sure of victory in November that it could look beyond a second Trump term to the legacy of his movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: An Olympics Scene Draws Scorn. Did It Really Parody ‘The Last Supper’?
description: Some church leaders and politicians have condemned the performance from the opening ceremony for mocking Christianity. Art historians are divided.
content: A performance during the Paris Olympics’ opening ceremony on Friday has drawn criticism from church leaders and conservative politicians for a perceived likeness to Leonardo da Vinci’s depiction of a biblical scene in “The Last Supper,” with some calling it a “mockery” of Christianity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: ‘The Righteous’ Brings Stirring Prayer to Santa Fe Opera
description: Gregory Spears and Tracy K. Smith’s new work about an ambitious minister’s rise in the 1980s is that rarity in contemporary music: an original story.
content: We’ve had “The Shining” and “Cold Mountain,” “The Hours” and “Dead Man Walking,” and works based on the lives of Steve Jobs, Malcolm X and Frida Kahlo. “Lincoln in the Bardo” and “The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier and Clay” are coming soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Hulk Hogan Is Not the Only Way to Be a Man
description: The Democratic Party must join the battle for the hearts and minds of young men.
content: The Democratic Party must join the battle for the hearts and minds of young men. It matters not just for this election, though the vast and growing gender gap means that disaffected men could hand Donald Trump the presidency. It matters for how we mentor young men, and it matters for how we view masculinity itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Russia Punches Through Weakened Lines in Eastern Ukraine
description: Military analysts say Russian forces are increasingly investigating Ukrainian lines to identify weakened positions before attacking and breaking through.
content: Russian forces have made rapid gains in the eastern Donetsk region over the past week or so, capturing a few villages and closing in on the city of Pokrovsk, one of the main Ukrainian defensive strongholds in the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: The Quiet Bond Kamala Harris Forged With Three V.P. Contenders
description: The vice president is considering several men who also served as state attorneys general. Those relationships could inform her crucial decision in the days ahead.
content: Keep up with the latest 2024 election news on Kamala Harris and Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Haley Willis, Aric Toler, David A. Fahrenthold and Adam Goldman
title: Gunman at Trump Rally Was Often a Step Ahead of the Secret Service
description: Text messages, obtained exclusively by The Times, indicate that some law enforcement officers were aware of Thomas Crooks earlier than previously known. And he was aware of them.
content: Nearly 100 minutes before former President Donald J. Trump took the stage in Butler, Pa., a local countersniper who was part of the broader security detail let his colleagues know his shift was ending.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Who Is Eminem for in 2024?
description: A conversation about the Detroit rapper’s long and unlikely career as his 12th studio album reaches No. 1.
content: The 12th studio album by Eminem, “The Death of Slim Shady (Coup de Grâce),” just had its debut atop the Billboard album chart, 25 years after the rapper’s major-label debut launched him into the pop stratosphere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Kate Christobek
title: At the N.R.A., a Battle Between the Old Guard and the New
description: The new chief executive is at odds with the new board president, just as the organization is arguing against a court-ordered monitor to oversee its finances.
content: The National Rifle Association’s new chief executive, Doug Hamlin, was elected only in mid-May, but he is already confronting a monumental obstacle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Quick Drive Around Town
description: Jeffrey Lease doubles down.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: A Memoir That Delivers on Its Promise of ‘Sex, Drugs, and Opera’
description: In “Seeing Through,” the prolific composer Ricky Ian Gordon shares the heroes, monsters, obsessions and fetishes that drive his art and fuel a dizzying life.
content: Even devotees of symphony orchestras sometimes struggle with the opera — its muchness and pomp. “The uproar,” my father called it, and he was a serious amateur chamber musician who collected and played the works of obscure composers on a Montagnana violin that he most certainly would have saved from a fire before my guinea pig, Percolator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony DePalma
title: Edna O’Brien, Writer Who Gave Voice to Women’s Passions, Dies at 93
description: Her novels and short stories often explored the lives of willful women who loved men who were crass, unfaithful or already married.
content: Edna O’Brien, the prolific Irish author whose evocative and explicit stories of loves lost earned her a literary reputation that matched the darkly complex lives of her tragic heroines, died on Saturday. She was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Marina Abramovic Wants to Live, Laugh, Love
description: At 77, the famous performance artist is determined to endure past 100. She recently introduced some products she hopes will help.
content: Marina Abramovic stood and faced the ocean on Fire Island.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Toxic Families: Is Breaking Away the Answer?
description: Responses to a Science Times article. Also: The joys of a foreign language; Donald Trump’s platform changes; a Long Island militia; understanding sloths.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Elizabeth Taylor: The Lost Tapes’ and ‘House of the Dragon’
description: HBO airs a new documentary. The “Game of Thrones” spinoff wraps up its second season.
content: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, July 29-August 4. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taffy Brodesser-Akner, Gabra Zackman, Adrienne Hurst, Aaron Esposito, Krish Seenivasan, John Woo, Marion Lozano and Ted Blaisdell
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Kidnapping I Can’t Escape’
description: Fifty years ago, her father’s friend was taken at gunpoint on Long Island. Then he went on with his life — and that’s the part that haunts her.
content: On Nov. 12, 1974, Taffy Brodesser-Akner’s father’s childhood friend Jack Teich was kidnapped out of his driveway in the nicest part of the nicest part of Long Island. He was arriving home from work when two men forced him into their car at gunpoint and took him to a house where they chained and interrogated him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Klitzman
title: 14 Questions About Our Leaders’ Health
description: Voters deserve transparency.
content: There’s been enormous debate about the health of America’s president and that of the candidates for that job. Many questions remain unanswered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Jill Schary Robinson, Who Wrote of Her Hollywood Upbringing, Dies at 88
description: A screenwriter’s daughter, she grew up in the glittering world of privilege and its contradictions, which became rich material for her memoirs and novels.
content: Jill Schary Robinson, an author and journalist who limned her glittering, complicated Hollywood upbringing in much of her work, beginning with her wry 1963 memoir, “With a Cast of Thousands,” and who found fame for chronicling Hollywood’s darker side a decade later in “Bed/Time/Story,” died on July 19 at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Business Is Buzzing Again for the Meme Makers of the Left
description: After a few sluggish years under President Biden, liberal social media creators are seeing their messages resonate as Kamala Harris campaigns for the White House.
content: Last Sunday, after President Biden announced he was stepping down from his presidential campaign and endorsing Kamala Harris as his replacement, Democratic meme makers rejoiced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Eric Schmitt
title: As F-16s Arrive, Ukraine Still Faces Steep Challenges in the Skies
description: Ukraine wants to deploy its first F-16 jets this summer, hoping to counter Russia’s dominance in the air. But stepped-up Russian bombing attacks on air bases complicate the effort.
content: The surveillance drone appeared high above the Ukrainian air base without warning in early July. Minutes after it relayed targeting data back to a Russian base, a barrage of ballistic missiles struck the airfield, Ukrainian officials said, recounting the episode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 414, July 29, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 28, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 28, 2024.
content: An article last Sunday about work by Wael Shawky described incorrectly the transfer of power in Egypt after Hosni Mubarak was deposed. Mohamed Morsi was elected, and then Abdel Fattah el-Sisi came to power. El-Sisi was not in power directly after Mubarak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Euan Ward and Isabel Kershner
title: Fears of Escalation After Rocket From Lebanon Hits Soccer Field
description: Diplomats were scrambling to prevent a surge in fighting, officials said, after Israel retaliated for the rocket fire that killed at least 12 children and teenagers in an Israeli-controlled town.
content: Western diplomats were scrambling on Sunday to prevent a surge of fighting along the Israel-Lebanon border, officials said, after a rocket from Lebanon on Saturday killed at least 12 children and teenagers in an Israeli-controlled town. The rocket prompted Israel to retaliate early Sunday with strikes across Lebanon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Weiyi Cai, Bedel Saget, Maggie Astor, Noah Throop, Emily Rhyne, Jeremy White and Joe Ward
title: The Move That May Take Sunisa Lee’s Name
description: Sunisa Lee has been practicing a new difficult element in her uneven bars routine. If she completes it at the Olympics, it will be named “The Lee.”
content: Sunisa Lee has been practicing a new difficult element in her uneven bars routine. If she completes it at the Olympics, it will be named “The Lee.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Video Shows Aftermath of Strike on Israeli-Controlled Golan Heights
description: Israel blamed Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed Lebanese military group, for an attack on a soccer field that killed 12 children and teenagers. Hezbollah has denied responsibility.
content: Israel blamed Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed Lebanese military group, for an attack on a soccer field that killed 12 children and teenagers. Hezbollah has denied responsibility.
source.name: The New York Times
